*Knock, knock.* The bell above the door chimed as I stormed into the vintage trinket shop, hands on my hips, eyes scanning the cluttered shelves. "Hey, what's this?" I grabbed an old silver-plated compact mirror, giving it a once-over before snapping it open and holding it up to my face.

The elderly woman behind the counter looked at me, her eyebrows raised slightly. She'd been arranging some jewelry boxes when I barged in. I could see it in her eyes, she was thinking, "Here we go again with another complaining customer."

"See these engravings?" I said, pointing to the intricate patterns on the mirror's surface. "They're all worn down. How can you sell something like this?"

She took a deep breath, walking over to me. "Sir, that mirror is antique. It's not supposed to be perfect. It has character."

"Character my ass," I retorted, holding it out towards her. "You think I'm gonna buy something with 'character' when it barely reflects my face? It's practically useless!"

She took the mirror from me, examining it closely. "It works just fine," she said calmly, showing me her reflection in it.

"Yeah, because you're standing right next to a lamp!" I shot back. "Prove it. Show me it works perfectly under normal light."

She sighed, taking the mirror and walking towards the window. She held it up again, this time angling it so the sunlight hit it directly. Her reflection was clear as day.

"See?" she said, turning to me. "It's fine."

I scoffed, crossing my arms. "You're just saying that because you want me to buy it. Prove it without trying to sell me on it."
